raw_text:
Low-budget film wins Cesar
 
 A film that follows a group of alienated youth in a Paris suburb as they prepare to perform an 18th Century play has won France's top cinema award.
 
 L'Esquive earned a Cesar prize for its director, Tunisian-born Abdellatif Kechiche, and its young star, the 18-year-old actress Sara Forestier. It saw off competition from big-budget French epic, A Very Long Engagement, and the box-office hit, The Chorus. US film Lost in Translation won the award for best foreign feature. The wistful romantic comedy directed by Sofia Coppola has already won several awards, including an Oscar for best screenplay in 2004. Its late release in France made it a contender for this year's Cesars.
 
 The low-budget L'Esquive depicts the travails of a group of youth getting ready to perform a school play by the 18th-Century dramatist, Marivaux. The actors are mostly amateurs and the action is set in the impoverished suburbs of Paris, home to thousands of immigrants from North Africa and their children. Kechiche said he made the film because he "wanted to show people we don't normally see at the cinema". A Very Long Engagement, a World War I drama featuring Audrey Tautou, won five Cesar awards. The Chorus, a film about a schoolteacher who introduces an unruly classroom to the pleasures of classical singing, won two awards - for best music and best sound. US actor Will Smith, who won an honorary award at the ceremony, thanked his family and his "hero", Nelson Mandela, in his speech.
llama3.2:1b:
Low-budget film wins Cesar prize
L'Esquive, a low-budget French film about alienated youth preparing for an 18th-Century play, has won France's top cinema award.
The film, directed by Tunisian-born Abdellatif Kechiche, and starring 18-year-old actress Sara Forestier, earned the Cesar prize for director and young star.
L'Esquive was released in late France and competed with big-budget films A Very Long Engagement and The Chorus at the ceremony.
It beat out other contenders to win the award for best foreign feature.
The film depicts the struggles of a group of youth preparing for a school play by Marivaux, set against the backdrop of impoverished Parisian suburbs home to North African immigrants.
llama3.2:3b: A low-budget film L'Esquive about a group of alienated youth performing an 18th Century play won France's Cesar award for its director Abdellatif Kechiche and young star Sara Forestier.
US film Lost in Translation won the award for best foreign feature beating A Very Long Engagement and The Chorus to win several awards including a 2004 Oscar for best screenplay.

Other award winners include "A Very Long Engagement" (5 Cesars), and "The Chorus" (2 Cesars).
"Lost in Translation" won best foreign feature.

The film outperformed big-budget films such as A Very Long Engagement and Lost in Translation, which also received nominations.
It was one of the few films to win awards from foreign and US theaters alike.

L'Esquive won the Cesar prize for its director Abdellatif Kechiche and young star Sara Forestier.
The film follows a group of French teenagers preparing to perform a 18th-century play.
It was one of the few films that won awards from foreign and US theaters alike, including Oscar nominations.

L'Esquive depicts the trials of amateur actors preparing to perform a Marivaux school play in impoverished Parisian suburbs, making it a standout choice among this year's competition.

Directed by Tunisian-born Abdellatif Kechiche and starring 18-year-old Sara Forestier, it defeated big-budget French films like A Very Long Engagement and The Chorus to win the Cesar for best film.
L'Esquive focuses on a group of amateur actors in impoverished Paris suburbs.
In contrast, A Very Long Engagement won five Cesar awards as a World War I drama with Audrey Tautou, while The Chorus received two honors including for best music and sound.
US actor Will Smith was awarded an honorary prize and thanked his family and Nelson Mandela.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Low-budget film L'Esquive, directed by Tunisian actress Abdellatif Kechiche and starring 18-year-old Sara Forestier, won the Cesar Prize.

Depicting a group of youth preparing for a school play by Marivaux, it received several awards, including an OSSO Best Director, Best Directed Film, Best Actress, Best Music, Best Sound, and Honorary Mention.
tinyllama:1.1b:
Loew-budget film wins Cesar for low-budget L'Esquive

A film that follows a group of disillusioned young people preparing to perform an 18th-Century play in a Paris suburb, winning France's top cinema award, the Cesar, has earned praise from critics.

The low-budget L'Esquive, directed by Tunisian-born Abdellatiif Kechiche, saw off competition from big-budget Frecnch epic A Very Long Engagement and the box-office hit The Chorus, directed by US film Lost in Translation.

L'Esquive depicted the trials of a group of amateur actors getting ready for their school play about Mariuaxtheatre, performed by the 18th-Century dramatis, which took place in impoverished suburbs of Paris, home to thousands of immigrants from North Africa and their children.

Kechiche said he made the film because he "wanted people who are not normally seen at cinema", with Audrey Taoutu receiving a Cesar for best actress and the French film A Very Long Engagement winning five awards in total.
The ceremony also celebrated US actor Will Smith, who won an honorary award, with family and Nelson Mandela, praised by his speech.
tinydolphin:1.1b: L'Esquive is a low-budget film that won the Cesar for Best Film in France this year, beating big-budget French epic A Very Long Engagement and The Chorus from the US.
Directed by Abdellatif Kechiche, it tells the story of a group of young Parisian actors rehearsing an 18th-century play while grappling with their own personal issues in a suburban neighborhood.
L'Esquive offers a humorous and inspiring glimpse into the lives of these amateurs, showcasing the beauty and joy of working together despite their differences.

The director, Abdellatif Kechiche, praised L'Esquive for showing "people we don't normally see at the cinema".

Set in impoverished Paris suburbs, L'Esquive follows a group of alienated youth preparing to perform an 18th-century play by Marivaux, highlighting the lives of often overlooked urban residents.
Kechiche intended the film to showcase these underrepresented individuals at the cinema.
A World War I drama, A Very Long Engagement, won five Cesars, while The Chorus secured two awards for best music and sound.
US actor Will Smith received an honorary Cesar, expressing gratitude for his family and Nelson Mandela during the ceremony.
